The statement is describing two different techniques that can be used to improve the performance of a model for depression estimation: Multi-class Uncertainty Sampling with Distribution Learning (MUSDL) and the Self-paced Adaptive Multi-task Learning (SAM) method.

1. Multi-class Uncertainty Sampling with Distribution Learning (MUSDL): It is a score distribution generation technique that is used to convert hard-labels in the Ground Truth (GT) to soft-label score distributions for soft decisions. The idea behind this technique is to use the uncertainty of the model's predictions as a guide for selecting the most informative samples for training. The technique learns a score distribution for each class, which can be used to make soft predictions.
2. Self-paced Adaptive Multi-task Learning (SAM): It is a second-order optimization method that is specifically designed to improve the generalization ability of the model, even when training on a small dataset. The SAM method is based on the idea of self-paced learning, which means that the model starts by learning the most informative samples, and gradually increases the difficulty of the samples as the model becomes more confident. Additionally, SAM is a multi-task learning method, which means that it can handle multiple related tasks, such as different severity levels of depression, and adapt the learning process accordingly.

Both MUSDL and SAM have been proven to improve the performance of the depression estimation models in a common case of small datasets, by leveraging the uncertainty of the model's predictions and the relatedness of different tasks.
